reviewText: I went to the midnight show of Disney's 'A Christmas Carol' last night and going into it, I was really excited. I was lucky enough to see the train tour that went around the country to promote the film and even got to see director Robert Zemeckis talk about the film at the D23 Expo. I'm a big fan of the Charles Dickens story as well, of course my two favorite film versions star Kermit the Frog and Mickey Mouse.Disney's new motion capture film is wonderful! I absolutely loved it, and I'm usually not a fan of motion capture. Jim Carrey is fabulous as Scrooge and the three ghosts. This adaptation is more faithful to the Charles Dickens classic than any other film version. In fact, it even begins with the opening of the book. And I found the 3D to be more impressive than Disney's previous 3D releases. In this film, items appear to pop off the screen and into the theater.Overall, I loved this new version and will definitely see it again in theaters. However, I must warn anybody with small children that this film is scary. In fact, it made me jump twice. I have to say that my favorite film version is still 'The Muppet Christmas Carol,' mainly because it's fun and has a lighter tone, but this new version is very good. This is sure to become an annual tradition for families to watch every holiday season.

reviewText: This film has been completely rendered in CGI.  As such it has some advantages over, and yet alternatively suffers when compared to, the best live action dramas.  In addition, this production cannot seem to decide whether it is to be a dark yet faithful adaptation of Dickens' work, or a pratfall-strewn, cartoon comedy.  With feet in both camps, it ends up unsuccessful in each.  There can be no question that CGI can offer a lot to enhance such a costume drama.  Every inanimate object was rendered faithfully and sometimes astonishingly.  The city of London in the 19th century was wonderfully presented.  The filming of Spirits and other spectral events can be greatly enhanced by CGI effects.  But ultimately it is the characters that sell the story.  The animated people in this production looked waxy and unrealistic.  Facial expressions lacked the sublime subtlety of reality.  Eyes were glassy and expressionless resembling audio-animatronic figures more than real human beings.  Things were not helped by the screenwriters' inability to come to grips with how they wanted to tell the story.  The pratfalls and comic chases clashed alarmingly with the dark and creepy aspects of the rest of the story.  Much of the film was a straight telling of Dickens' tale and was obviously well-researched as many details provided in the novella were accurately rendered.  Yet in its schizophrenia, the film also chooses at times to dispense with any effort at accuracy or even verisimilitude by inserting ridiculous scenes of cartoon-like quality.  If one wants a satisfying cartoon version of the Dickens tale, both amusing and touching, one need only view Disney's "Mickey's Christmas Carol".  In short, while at times quite accurate, its deficiencies make it difficult to recommend this film as the most accurate filmic representation of Dickens.  You can read in more detail a comparison of this and other film treatments of Dickens' classic at dickenscroogemovies dot com.

reviewText: As an English teacher who's taught the novel for over ten years, I'm very familiar with the story Dickens crafted.  He is a master of the English language, and of story telling.  While Disney studios know how to do animation, they and Robert Zemeckis fell short on this adaptation.ORIGINAL STORY: It is important to know that when Dickens wrote his novel, few people celebrated Christmas; in fact, the holiday was more or less ignored by most of the world.  The Industrial Revolution was in full swing in England, and a large portion of the population was extremely poor.  Those that weren't tended to be business owners, who were rather selfish and greedy, and treated their workers poorly.  Dickens' intent in writing the story was to use this well-known but little-celebrated holiday as a touch-point for his Unitarian beliefs (which basically suggested that all people should unite [thus, "Unitarians"] to help each other and make the world a better place) and get the rich to help the poor, and the poor to help each other, so that all people could live happier lives. As an allegory, the novel features Scrooge, who symbolically represents the repressive and greedy business owners of the time, ill-treating his clerk Bob, symbolically representative of the thoughtful and kind but poor working class. The story is presented in five chapters (called "staves, the plural of the musical term "staff", since this is a Christmas "carol"), each of which has a specific function.  The first introduces the main character, Ebenezer Scrooge, describing his miserliness and presenting him with a supernatural visitation from his former partner, now a tormented ghost who sees that Scrooge will have the same torments when he dies if Scrooge does not change his ways.  The second stave deals with Scrooge's past, and how he became the horrible person he is.  The third stave details Dickens' ideas of a perfect Christmas, and how even the poorest of the poor can find happiness in the day.  The fourth stave deals with Scrooge's potential future if he does not change his ways.  The final stave explains how all of this has affected Scrooge.MOVIE ADAPTATION: When it comes to the movie adaptation, the whole affair begins rather well with an adaptation of the first few pages of the novel; the interpretation is interesting, and generally captures the concept Dickens was going for.  Zemeckis made the choice to not have a narrator for the story (until the very last scene), which is curious, since the story specifically has a narrator that interacts with the audience and help clarify certain portions of the book.  This would have been a useful addition, especially for some scenes that are relatively faithful to the language of 1840's England that will undoubtedly leave modern audiences, and especially the young, confused.I was very pleased at the accuracy of the dialogue and general action of the first few scenes after the introduction, but grew worried during the famous scene with Marley's face appearing on Scrooge's door knocker.  Zemeckis added an overly-dramatic twist to the scene which didn't add anything to the story and which sets up an expectation that the story will be much scarier and action-filled than it actually is.Jacob Marley's arrival as a ghost was rather well-done, and captured the spirit of the scene (pardon the pun), if not hewing to the actual word.  This is when I grew more curious - Zemeckis had initially followed the book rather faithfully up until this point (barring the introduction), and this scene turned out to be the beginning of every-greater swings away from the actual story as written by Dickens, both in the letter and in essence.Completely neglecting the fact that Scrooge falls asleep and sleeps through an entire day, things started to get ever-farther away from the original text with the arrival of the Spirit of Christmas Past.  A few scenes are neglected that help the audience truly get a sense of how Scrooge came by his dislike of the holiday, and which show how he actually did enjoy some of his Christmases.  One of the most important scenes that didn't make it into the movie is Scrooge's completely unselfconscious discussion with the Spirit about how his old boss, Fezziwig, made people happy without having to spend much money, and how happiness is, in fact, more important than money; this leads Scrooge to speculate that he could make his own employee much happier very easily.  This is a seminal moment in the story, in that it plants the first of many seeds in Scrooge's mind about how he should behave, and helps Scrooge begin to re-connect with humanity.  Still, the story is generally (if not specifically) faithful to the original, and provides a basic understanding of how Scrooge became the man he is.It is with the next scene that the wheels really start to come off the train.  Again, the perceived passage of time is ignored (which makes Scrooge's amazement about how it's Christmas Day at the end of the movie completely irrelevant).  Zemeckis makes some very unusual choices in staging the scenes with the Spirit of Christmas Present.  First and foremost is the (rather literal) framing device used as the Spirit begins to show Scrooge the wonders of Christmas Day - it is distracting from the action, and completely unnecessary.  It was in this section of the story that Zemeckis and Disney seem to decide that they know more about how to structure a story than one of the greatest writers of all time.  Major sections of the third chapter of the novel are completely left out, and this is a shame.  Dickens did not include these scenes lightly - they serve the important narrative purpose of pointing out to the audience what a perfect Christmas is supposed to be like (and, indeed, on which many of our modern celebrations of the holidays are founded), and providing Scrooge with insight into the lives of people he has treated poorly.  These scenes are, at best, truncated, and most are simply left out.  The final scene in this section of the story is wildly over-the-top, and though it does do a decent job of summarizing some of the symbolism in a narrative fashion, it is extremely grim and dark, much more so than Dickens probably intended.The visit of the final spirit, of Christmas Yet to Come, is completely ridiculous and bears little resemblance to what is related in the novel.  There is a five minute chase scene that has absolutely nothing to do with the story, and is not very entertaining to watch even on its own.The concluding part of the story goes back to being rather faithful to the source material.Overall, the story is very disjointed, and does not capture the original very well past the first quarter of the movie.  As my wife said, "It's as if they split the story into pieces and had five different people work on each piece in isolation, then slapped all the sections together at the end."
summary: Disney tries to "improve" Dickens, and fails

In some ways, Robert Zemeckis misses the point of this Christmas story and in an effort to make this film an "experience" for 3D theater viewers, especially children, he sacrifices story and character for cheap amusement park thrill ride.  In A Christmas Carol, the story still comes through and many elements of the original story appear that are often not included in other film versions of this story.  Unlike the Polar Express, the music in this film is nowhere near as memorable.

reviewText: This film was a disappointment, especially given that it was helmed by one of Hollywood's best directors, Robert Zemeckis.Most people are probably aware of Charles Dickens classic story about an embittered old man being visited by three ghosts on Christmas Eve in a final attempt to salvage his humanity. Most of us eagerly anticipate the latest revisioning of this beloved tale, but its success or failure depends on if we emotionally connect to the characters enough to share in Scrooge's warm and fuzzy transformation at the end of the tale.There were some interesting riffs off old ideas, but unfortunately this version simply didn't work for me.  The style of animation was weirdly cold and artificial - it felt like watching someone play a "Christmas Carol" game on Xbox or PS3. Too bad Disney didn't tap Pixar for this.The end of the visitation by the ghost of Christmas Present added to the overall macabre vibe.This story has many superior previous versions, including the classicA Christmas Carol [Blu-ray] and the often malignedScrooge

reviewText: I have never written a review after having been an Amazon customer for over 8 years now at least, however, after seeing the dreadful amount of reviews for the movie, I had to make sure I gave it a 5 star review.  I consider myself a "Christmas Carol" movie buff (of my own making of course), and this version is so close to perfect that it deserves the highest of all reviews.  For those who say that this was meant to be an uplifting story and is too 'scary', I suppose you have never taken the time to read the book.  It is a story of redemption, and of turning a miserable miser into a completely uplifted new man.  A man that was given a second chance at life...and I am sorry, but it would have sickened me to see them portray this otherwise.  In order for man to change, they must see their wrongs and the repercussions that will happen if life is continued being lived without care of others, and this is exactly what Dicken's was portraying, and what the movie came across as. To see it all 'fluffed' up and 'Disney'd' up would just be ridiculing what Dicken's was trying to prove.  I personally love the version with George C. Scott, as well as the classic with Alastair Sim, but when I saw this first last year, I knew that there was a new classic.  All the parts, minor as they may be, that have been left out of previous versions were included, and I thought that this movie hit the book to the 't' and am so glad to have this movie to pass down to others, to show what the book was truly supposed to be like when coming to life in Hollywood.  For those who feel it is too scary, I suggest you show your children Sesame Street or something of the like, because I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but guess what?  Life is not always good, sometimes it can be downright harsh....and this movie put to life what happens when a man who has been a terrible person both inside his heart and out gets a chance at redemption...a second chance to live, and if this is not something your children may understand at their young age, then you may want to just put this on the shelf for a few more years until they realize that life is not full of marshmallows and happiness 24 hours a day....otherwise, sit down and enjoy the movie of a lifetime!
summary: Needed to raise the star level!

reviewText: When you see Jim Carrey portraying a lot of characters in a movie, you get excited because you know the potential he has when creativity is allowed (The Mask, for example). Unfortunately, this movie doesn't take advantage of their star. As a matter of fact, practically anyone could have played the roles he was given with the same excitement.The effects here are amazing, and the computer animation is wonderful. Their treatment of Marley's Ghost is by far the best of any Christmas Carol movie I've seen. It's actually scary, which is good. However, Jim's performance as Scrooge and the ghosts seems basically phoned in. He's playing the characters pretty much standard as any other version of the film. His interpretation of the Ghost of Christmas Past is actually the weakest I've seen (their decision for his overall design was strange anyway). This is one time they probably would have come off better to just let him play Scrooge and give the ghosts to someone else. Gary Oldham does a great job as Cratchit and Marley, actually stealing the show from Carrey's generic Scrooge.Don't get me wrong, I wasn't expecting Scrooge to play like Ace Ventura or anything, but it would have been nice to see a little spark of fun in there somewhere. It seemed to me that Carrey was actually bored with the roles (since this was motion captured from him).Still, it's nice to see "A Christmas Carol" on screen again. This is pretty much a fairly standard version of the story and probably won't be considered "must see" for the holiday season after this year (like "It's a Wonderful Life" or even other versions of "Christmas Carol"), but it was nice to see the 3D take on it.

reviewText: Okay, so motion capture animation has gotten a little better, but more on that later!I've reviewed a few versions of "A Christmas Carol" here on Amazon and finally got around to watching this one. Everybody knows the story about Scrooge by now, and I'm too lazy to go over the synopsis, but I will say much of this adaption is beautifully made and it's fairly faithful to Dickens...fairly.I suppose we've come to expect cinematic adaptations to be a bit over the top. So when Disney and Jim Carrey decided to come out with their own interpretation of Ebenezer Scrooge, we had to know there would be physical comedy, chase scenes and overt sentimentality. It certainly wouldn't have the subtlety of Masterpiece Theater (although wouldn't you love to see their take on the story starring someone like, say, Ian McKellen as Scrooge?) Anyway, over the top is certainly what we got. And I don't mind seeing Scrooge flying over London from the second story of his house, or being chased through the streets by a ghostly horse-drawn carriage, or even needlessly shrinking down to the size of a mouse. The problem is there's SO MUCH of this kind of junk involved, it truncates the spirit of the story. If you were to strip away all the goofy additional material, you would realize you're watching nothing but cliffnotes in motion capture. For example, it just seemed odd that Scrooge would get emotional about Tiny Tim's plight considering he barely had time to connect with the lad.As far as the horse-drawn carriage chase and the Scrooge-shrinkage, the problem is they go on WAY too long! And it seems to me, the purpose of Scrooge witnessing some of these events in the future are defeated while he's preoccupied fleeing from the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come through London streets or avoiding blows from a poker wielded by Old Joe! You'll see what I mean, when you watch the movie.Jim Carrey actually does a pretty good job as Scrooge. I just don't understand why him. It seems like any number of fine British actors could have voiced the role, or motion captured the role, or whatever the heck you want to call it. He's not particularly impressive as the Ghost of Christmas Present, however, who's maniacal laughing only annoys after a while. Speaking of the Ghost of Christmas Present, what a horrible way to depict his demise. Nothing expresses "Merry Christmas" like watching a jolly bearded ghost waste away to bone and ash! Speaking of macabre imagery, I know they meant to be funny when Jacob Marley's jaw cracks open, but double-u-tee-eff? I'm starting to think they missed the boat not having Scrooge resemble Vincent Price! It all would have made sense then! Oh, and I have no idea what was going on with Marley's eyes.All the other voices were fine, except Colin Firth. An actor I normally love, he seemed to over exaggerate his vocal performance...like he was all too aware he was in an animated feature.Now about this whole motion capture business. I know they've made some advances in the technology. And it's true the job done on Scrooge himself is the best we've seen so far. But as impressive has his character looks, everyone else still looked (as Dickens described Jacob Marley) dead as a doornail! They just haven't mastered the eyes of the characters and can't shake the creep factor. Perhaps there's something to be said for traditional animation that Robert Zemeckis hasn't figured out. Animated characters should LOOK like animated characters...exaggerated features and all. The more animation strives for reality, the more perfect they need to be in capturing the details, especially the eyes, which are called the "windows of the soul" for a reason.These Zemeckis characters are still soulless creatures unable to depict the subtle emotions of Bugs Bunny, let alone a flesh and blood actor!I wouldn't say this is the worst adaptation of "A Christmas Carol" I've ever seen as it is handsomely made and highly energetic. Plus, I was intrigued by the Ghost of Christmas Present's lecture regarding "men of the cloth". Still, it's pretty close to being the worst!

reviewText: The story of "A Christmas Carol" and its themes haven't been fresh in people's minds for well over 100 years, which is why the new film adaptation by Robert Zemeckis is so surprising. This is, from my perspective, the definitive version - a sumptuous visual feast that in no way compromises the drama, excitement, and hope of the Charles Dickens classic. Its greatest achievement is not reducing itself to the level of jolly Christmas clichés. The streets and buildings of nineteenth-century London are brightly coated with snow, yet they betray the cold reality of poverty and despair. And Ebenezer Scrooge, having been played by many, many actors over the years, finally looks like the ancient, decrepit, bitter man I always imagined him to be; his face doesn't show the slightest trace of warmth, humor, or charm.The film's success can be attributed to Zemeckis' love affair with special effects, which in this case involves the same motion capture technology he employed in "The Polar Express" and "Beowulf." This allows for the creation of characters caught in that delightful gray zone between real and unreal. Some are more exaggerated than others; Scrooge - a little too tall, a little too thin, a little too hunched over - is a menacing physical representation of his own anger and resentment. The Ghost of Christmas Past, an elfin wraith with a breathy voice and a head made of fire, is as slight, slender, and soft-spoken as a candle. The Ghost of Christmas Present is a loud and jovial Father Christmas figure, whose laugh is just as big as his body, perhaps bigger. The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is a silent yet frightening skeletal phantom made out of shadows.Scrooge and the Ghosts are all played by Jim Carrey, which hardly comes as a shock since he has an affinity for variety of character and over the top performances. Other actors include Gary Oldman as Bob Crachit, Tiny Tim, and Jacob Marley, whose postmortem appearance in Scrooge's bedchamber is intensely creepy, just as it should be. Robin Wright Penn plays both Scrooge's younger sister, Fen, and his neglected fiancée, Belle. Bob Hoskins plays old Fezziwig, a man so thoroughly in the Christmas spirit that he and his wife defy gravity as they dance. Colin Firth plays Scrooge's hopelessly optimistic nephew Fred, quite possibly the only person who thinks his uncle is worth addressing in a friendly manner.As Scrooge is taken on his journey of redemption, both he and the audience are treated to fantastic aerial tours of London, with shots that swoop and soar over rooftops, through windows, and around street corners. 3-D technology, normally so unimpressive, is here perfectly utilized, allowing for one of the most immersive environments of any recent animated film. One of the most stunning sequences involves a spectral carriage chasing a shrunken Scrooge up and down dark, snowy cobblestone streets; it's not only an astounding visual achievement, it's also an exhilarating thrill ride. Harkening back to the roller coaster train sequences created for "The Polar Express," Zemeckis proves that you should stick with what works best.There are also some equally effective quiet moments, such as the opening shot, which pays homage to classic Disney animated films with the opening of a book. Other moments are surprisingly powerful, as when a grieving Bob Cratchit, his eyes red with tears, seems to be staring directly at Scrooge even though he can't really see him (Cratchit, in that moment, is nothing more than a vision of the future). I also appreciated the shot of doomed ghosts floating just outside Scrooge's window; some of them act humorously, banging their heads against their chain boxes, and yet we can't help but feel sorry for them.The entire film embodies a darker, shivery tone - not to the point of becoming a computer-animated horror film, but certainly beyond the colorful whimsy of the average Christmas special. This, I believe, truly captures the tone of Dickens' original story, which doesn't spare the reader the hardships of destitution, disease, and loss. Consider Bob Cratchit's family; they do make merry of themselves on Christmas Day, but they also live a meager existence, and there's always the sense that, should nothing about their situation change, they could end up with even less.Robert Zemeckis created a perennial holiday classic with "The Polar Express," and I think he may have done it again with "A Christmas Carol." Yes, we have seen this movie before, and yes, its message is far from original. But there's no denying the fact that it's sending a good message, where love, compassion, and the possibility of hope reign supreme. There's also no denying that, with visuals this striking, it practically begs to be seen, especially in 3-D. This is one of the year's best looking animated films, so richly detailed, so sharply defined, so gloriously shot. It creates a mood, effectively evoking feelings of warmth and tenderness without becoming sappy or mindlessly cheerful. That above all made seeing this film an absolutely beautiful experience, one that I recommend to everybody.
summary: A New Look for a Classic Story

reviewText: A CHRISTMAS CAROLSTARRING: The Voices of: Jim Carrey, Gary Oldman, Colin Firth, Robin Wright Penn, Bob Hoskins and Carey ElwesWRITTEN BY: Robert Zemeckis; based on the novel by Charles DickensDIRECTED BY: Robert ZemeckisRated: PGGenre: Animation / DramaRelease Date: 06 November 2009When it comes to animation, it doesn't get any better than the master himself; Robert Zemeckis. He changed the face of animation forever with his classic Who Framed Roger Rabbit. Years later he dazzled all of us with The Polar Express and his legendary adaptation of Beowulf. Now, he's done it once more with his latest masterpiece from Walt Disney: A Christmas Carol.I don't know of any story that's been retold more than this one, and rightfully so. It's been around for nearly 200 years, and I'm sure Zemeckis's version won't be the last to be seen.I'll take the liberty of assuming that everyone is familiar with the plot, and just highlight the key points: Ebenezer Scrooge absolutely despises Christmas and everything to do with it. He has a massive fortune but not so much as a single friend, and treats everyone like rubbish. Seven years after the death of his partner Jacob Marley, he will be visited by the ghost of Marley as well as three other specters (the ghosts of the past, present and future) on the night of Christmas Eve. The ghosts will show him visions of his past, present and future and the life he has lived and will live, if he does not change his twisted ways.You get what you'd expect from the plot, yes, and you've seen it a hundred times in other forms, yes; but you have never seen it quite like this. Despite being a huge Robert Zemeckis fan and maybe even a bigger fan of Jim Carrey, I too had these same thoughts going in. But as I was, you too will be amazed.The animation is nothing short of incredible. Several times in the film, I thought I was looking at real people and actual sets, for a few seconds. It's truly impressive. This will no-doubt be a must-own on Blu-ray! The colors are vibrant, the picture is crystal clear and the sound quality is truly spectacular.You can see Jim Carrey and Colin Firth and Gary Oldman, hidden in the characters they voice, and it's awesome! I'm sure that the actors physically acted out these scenes at some point during the process in addition to the voice-over-work, as their physical movements are all very life-like.Jim Carrey plays Ebenezer Scrooge exceptionally well and we have never seen the character more hideous and vial. He is terrifyingly thin and oddly hunched over and looks like he's ready to croak any second. His voice is raspy and dry and it makes your skin crawl.If you are expecting to laugh during the film, DON'T. The laughs are scarce as this is a very heavy drama indeed. In addition to the drama, it's very dark as well, so you may want to re-think taking smaller children. The spirits are scary and there are several moments where things jump out at you and make loud unsettling noises.What makes this so different from other versions of the classic Dickens tale, aside from the obvious beautiful look the film offers, are the moments where Scrooge is visited by the ghosts.Robert Zemeckis wrote the script in addition to directing the film, so it is very much his spin on things. The three entities are all different from what we have seen in versions of the past and they offer a nice touch to the story, cinematically. They don't crowd the scenes they're in. They take Scrooge where he needs to go, and offer him minimal guidance and that is good for the kids; they will be able to learn the valuable lessons of this story, from seeing what's happening with the characters, versus the ghosts telling us and Scrooge the implications his actions have and will cause.We also go on spectacular thrill-ride adventures with Scrooge as he is hurled through the streets of London, and shot into the sky like a rocket.Zemeckis and his team of animators have created a gorgeous London for this story to unfold in. I think that's one of the best elements to animation; you can create interesting and majestic worlds for your characters to live in, without limitations to reality and visual believability.There are a ton of animated movies that youngsters will love watching, but parents would rather have heart surgery than sit through. There are also several animated films parents don't want their kids to see due to its content and subject matter. Disney's A Christmas Carol is something parents will find comfort in their children watching, and they will undoubtedly enjoy themselves as well.

reviewText: I saw this movie last night and am glad that I slept on it before writing this review.First off, am I sorry that I went to see it?  Pretty much so. I think there was too much concentration on the action scenes.  The Ghost of Christmas Future sequence went on WAY TOO LONG.  The message to A Christmas Carol gets lost in the concentration on the action.  Scrooge being a greedy and unfeeling tyrant is there at the beginning but not brought out as much as the story progresses.  The story of Cratchitt (spelling?) is rather lost.  The story of Belle and Scrooge's courtship seems 'glazed over'.  The reason why Scrooge is left at boarding school as a boy was not really explained.  There are sequences of the movie that are good.  The Ghost of Christmas Present was entertaining at times.  I have put in the Patrick Stewart version of A Christmas Carol (which I HIGHLY recommend) to do a quick comparison before writing this review.Lastly, there is something about a Christmas movie that I look for that this movie tries to deliver at the end but comes up short.  I like a Christmas movie that can give me goose bumps, a good / warm feeling or perhaps draws a tear.  The whole redemption sequence at the end does deliver some of this, but it is too little too late.Should you see this movie?  I would not recommend it.  It definitely won't be purchased for my DVD collection.  If you are thinking about seeing it (and don't have small children), I would normally recommend seeing it for yourself to judge. reviewText: Disney's 2009 version of "A Christmas Carol" brings Charles Dickens' classic to vivid life with the dramatic animation over live acting that made "Polar Express" such an entrancing visual experience.  In the case of "A Christmas Carol", the effects are quite moving.  Londontown never looked so forbiding in the dark, nor so cheerful on Christmas morning.  The ghosts look as scary as they were meant to be; after all, "A Christmas Carol" is about motivating a stubborn old miser into better behavior.  The movie effectively captures all the essential elements of the story, including the presentations by the ghosts of past, present, and future.  If some scenes are a bit over the top, such as the exotic dancing at Old Fezziwig's, or Ebenezer's flying sequences, it's a bit of relief after Scrooge's unhappy confrontations with the ghosts.  Jiim Carrey does a terrific job behind the animation as Scrooge.  Highly recommended, as long as you like this particular style of animation.
Title: Disney's A Christmas Carol

reviewText: There have been many versions of this wonderful tale, some good, some bad, but none have been able to recreate the original story so faithfully and brilliantly. I am stunned that anyone would give this movie a poor rating and almost gave up on even trying to watch it because of these negative reviews. But today it was for 99 cents, too good to pass up. I'm glad I didn't.It is a wonderful, scary (like the story), beautiful, heartbreaking and uplifting film. Sure, kids will be scared at times and maybe parents should view it first to see if it is right for them. But even I was surprised and spooked by it. The sheer joy of finally seeing Dicken's vision fully realized from beginning to end made it a film for the ages. Jim Carrey, who disappears in his various characters, especially Scrooge, is just brilliant in his voice and mannerisms. I am stunned by his overall performance. And the animation is gorgeous in every way. I cannot find any fault in this film except to say I did not want it to end.For many reasons, A Christmas Carol has been one of my favorite story I revisit every Christmas in book, tv and film. Never has any form touched the Dickens original..until now. Yes, this film is that good. It is masterful.Ok, so there a few scenes omitted and some added and a change here and there but I loved every minute of it.I am going to buy this and watch it every year. It is so rare to see a film made with today's wondrous special effects but still held together by timeless storytelling.God Bless us, every one! (And Robert Zemeckis for making this)

reviewText: What would Christmas be without a visit to Charles Dickens' 'A Christmas Carol', a story that dates back to 1843 and has been loved and read every year at this time?  There have been other films, stage productions, musicals, and family readings galore and it still holds the magic of what the spirit of Christmas is all about.  Doubtless there will be flocks of naysayers who don't buy into this adaptation by Robert Zemekis, but given the ghost story magic Dickens' created, this film takes it one step further and makes the ghostly three spirits very much alive and beautiful fanciful.Combining the actors with animation (animating the actors might be a better way of describing the magic) makes each of the many very well known actors who portray the characters that much more credible.  Jim Carrey is at his peak as an actor in his ability to become the illusions his mind creates: he portrays all three ghosts as well a Scrooge at every level of his history.  Other actors who are transformed by Zemekis and staff include Gary Oldman as the trio of Cratchit, Marley's Ghost, and Tiny Tim, Colin Firth as the jovial nephew, Cary Elwes, Robin Wright Penn, Bob Hoskins, Fionnula Flanagan and a host of others.  The costumes and scenery are brilliantly executed.One problem with the film that may require parental judgment is the fact that the ghosts are truly scary and children might not be able to get past the fear they instill.  But they will grow into the film as it is likely a work that will be resurrected every Christmas season as a tradition.  It is 'excellent, my good fellows'.  Grady Harp, December 10
summary: Fine Interpretation for Adults: Not for all Children
Title: Disney's A Christmas Carol

reviewText: This is a superb movie.  Robert Zemeckis, Jim Carrey, Gary Oldman, et al. give us a movie of "A Christmas Carol" that, while animated, demands to be seen with the same sophistication and maturity level as its live-action counterparts.Actually, this reminds me of older Disney films, with the visual artistry of "Banbi" or "Peter Pan."  In more modern times, Japanese anime seems to be a stylistic influence on this picture.  Jim Carrey is positively brilliant as Ebenezzer Scrooge, in addition to every ghost outside of Jacob Marley.  It is truly astounding how Carrey makes the viewer forget his claim to fame as a comedian and marvel at his vocal work, as he effortlessly runs a very wide gamut that puts him in company with the animation vocal artist masters.Gary Oldman is also a standout vocally in three roles, as Bob Cratchit, Jacob Marley, and Tiny Tim.  As Marley, he is particularly impressive as a model of fierce repentance and conviction.If you're a parent of a young child, please try to take the time to screen this in advance of them seeing it.  It is not geared for children, and does not make storytelling concessions for them.  Every child is different, but I am trying to give a fair warning.This is a brilliant movie that does not sacrifice a mature Dickensian feel one bit.  It will probably be nominated for a Best Animated Feature Oscar, and I highly recommend seeing it.
summary: An animated film that quietly attempts to redefine American animation

reviewText: This animated adaptation of Charles Dickens', "A Christmas Carol," could well become the classic film version to 21st century kids as the Alistair Sims "Scrooge" became in the 1950s.  The animation is so 19th century authentic that it actually is continually illustrating the Victorian classic book.  It is true to the Dickens words and spirit.  From the beginning it is a visual-experiencing of olde London.  All that is missing is the smell of coal smoke and horse dung.It is not just Jim Carrey (Scrooge, 3 ghosts, & more) and Gary Oldman (Cratchit, Marley, Tiny Tim) that so passionately do the unforgettable characters' voices. Colin Firth, a necessary for any top quality Victorian London story, as Ebenezer's nephew Fred's voice, is animated to look the most like himself.Animated sets are thrilling and punctuated with moments like sliding down hilly iced-over cobblestone back streets, the coal soot patina on 1840s shops, and animated London fog looking more atmospheric than the real thing. Scrooge's bony fingers are as true-to-life as on an emaciated elderly man near death. Scrooge is himself a bit ghostly; like a more aged Lemony Snicket. And about as darkly evil.____(Excuse the name dropping, but with any great film--it is bound to be compared to other accomplishments.) Like the aerial flight through time where Scrooge is hand-held by a ghost.  It recalls images of Mary Martin in "Peter Pan."The 2nd 'Scottish' Spirit's home was a Victorian Christmas visual masterpiece of delight; and the trip through Christmas Present, more like floating with "Mary Poppins."  Spirit of the Future's trip adventure, however, depicted more peril than anything "Indiana Jones" ever encountered. Action! Misadventure! Fear!This film is technically animated beyond "Polar Express."  Characters' hair, snow & ice, and the Cratchit Christmas goose are all as aesthetically fine and real as any photography.The only negative for this adaptation to Dickens' Christmas Spirits' story is the inability to push a "play" button on a remote for a second viewing. I can't wait for a DVD version (next year?). For now, it's back to the box office.IT'S A CLASSIC-both book and film.  Don't do this Christmas without seeing it.  It's perfect for our economic times: the underlying theme that Christmas is about giving and family.  Take your family (as long as the kids are beyond 2nd grade). Preschoolers and early-elementary age might be frightened.  Remember the Dickens story is a bit on the dark side till the end.Don't leave till after the credits.  The song sung by Andrea Bocelli, "God Bless Us Everyone", (writers: Alan Silvestri, Glen Ballard) is at the end.  It could/SHOULD be on this year's Top-10 Christmas Song list.  Hear the words--they summarize the meaning of the story of Ebenezer.Anyone know, is that song on a CD yet?READ COMMENTS. A CD IS AVAILABLE BY BOCELLI WITH "GOD BLESS US EVERYONE".
summary: DICKENS, HIMSELF, WOULD RATE THIS FILM 5 GOLDEN SOVEREIGNS.

reviewText: Ever since it was first published in 1843, Charles Dickens' tale of miserly Scrooge and his redemption at the hands of various ghosts has long entranced readers with its message of holiday cheer.  It has been adapted numerous times for both stage and screen with a wide variety of distinguished actors such as Alistair Sim and George C. Scott taking on the Scrooge role.  This time, director Robert Zemeckis takes on the familiar story with the help of 3-D motion capture animation and the rubber-limbed talents of Jim Carrey.  What emerges is a flick that, despite its tendency to overuse the 3-D tricks of the trade, is a very faithful adaptation of the Dickens' work in both mood and detail.  In an unusual twist, Carrey not only tackles the role of miserly Scrooge in all his incarnations, but also the roles of all three of the Christmas Spirits who haunt him.  To his credit, Carrey chooses to underplay the miser, making him more believable as a result. He's also very effective in his interpretations of Christmas Past and Yet to Come, with only Christmas Present displaying any hint of his usual penchant to overact.  Carrey is also given solid support by Gary Oldman as Marley's Ghost and Bob Cratchit, Bob Hoskins' Fezziwig and Old Joe, and Robin Wright Penn's Belle and Fan.  Colin Firth provides a nice contrast to Carrey in his role of Fred, Scrooge's nephew.Zemeckis presents a handsome production that faithfully recreates Victorian London, supported by a wonderful soundtrack by Alan Silvestri.  Zemeckis' screenplay also does justice to the tale by presenting many of the darker themes that tend to get ignored in many other adaptations.  Indeed, it should be noted that some of the images might be considered too strong for very young audiences.  Overall, this film proves to be a delightfully strong entry into the list of worthy CAROL adaptations and definitely worth seeing.
summary: Disney presents a delightful version of Dickens' classic

reviewText: Because I'm a techno-geek, I went to the "Behind the Scenes" parts before I ever watched the movie.  While the creators patted themselves on the back about how faithful they were to the spirit (pun intended, I'm sure) of how Dickens probably visualized the movie, I had to see for myself, of course.Then I watched the movie.  All of my comments are based on what I have always felt about this classic.The good:* A very good Scrooge.  Jim Carrey's Scrooge is the Scrooge of my imagination, from my childhood.  This is one time I have to agree with the creators of the film.  This was the perfect Scrooge.* A very good Tiny Tim.  Ditto for everything I said about Scrooge, this was the perfect Tiny Tim.*  The doorknocker. FINALLY! One that's true to the book!*  Jacob Marley rocked. The best, ever. Dickens described the ghost of Marley as having an "atmosphere" about him and this movie displayed that.  This was great.* A very good Ghost of Christmas Past. While this is quite different from what I had always pictured, I liked the interpretation.* I'm in my late 50s and have been reading this book every year since I was a child (raised my children on that tradition), and have been disappointed with most movie characterizations of these main characters.  If it took "motion capture" to get there, then that's okay.  It works.* The scenery was stellar.* I have a blu-ray, so really enjoy the increased resolution. As expected, excellent Disney attention to detail.The not so good:* Miniaturizing Scrooge. Really?  Couldn't get past the silliness factor of that idea, especially since there seemed no plausible reason as to why it was necessary in the telling of the story.  How in the world was *that* true to what Dickens meant?* The whole 3D thing was, in my opinion, somewhat overdone.  There are a lot of great parts that I feel were left out in favor of the 3D experiences which had nothing to do with the book.*  The Ghost of Christmas Future had this whole Darth Vader-ish mojo going when they finally did a closeup of his face.*  Considering the amount of detail and work put into the movie overall, I was surprised that the ending was so truncated.  Not *disappointed* because it was more accurate than Scrooge running around the floor with a rat (this *is* Disney, after all), but surprised.* Little details of the book that somehow got either dropped or not fleshed out the way that I expected from a version that was supposed to be "very true to the spirit" of the book.The unfleshed:* Only one person in Old Joe's* Fred's party* Only one of the fund-raisers met with Scrooge after his experience* Bob Cratchit speaking of meeting Scrooge's nephew after Tiny Tim's deathand a few others...The deleted:* The hearse up the stairs.*  Scrooge's praises of Fezziwig*  The complete breakup of Scrooge & Belle*  Belle's family sceneThere were several others, but these few scenes were very key to the telling of the story, and I feel that they were eliminated because of the 3D action gimmickry parts.Overall, I felt that it was a very good interpretation of the book.  It may be a little scary for youngsters, but it *is,* after all, a Ghost story.  I found myself getting quite impatient with many of the parts made to emphasize the 3D effects (flying through the air over roofs and chimneys, getting stuck in the curtain rings, riding an icicle, etc.) because I felt that *some point* it detracted more than added to the quality of the movie.  I don't have a 3D tv yet, but I can see where it would be fun to watch. No, I didn't see the movie in the theaters.I would definitely recommend the movie.  I can see it becoming a family tradition, especially if there are young children around.  I bought it to show to my grandchildren for the holidays for years to come.  Too bad there's not a version for adults.
summary: Good, yes, but a Little Gimmicky

reviewText: This is Disney's third version of this story following "Mickey's Christmas Carol" and "The Muppet's Christmas Carol". The third time's not the charm; this rendition is my all time least favorite edition of Dicken's classic.There's a story in Ray Bradbury's "The Illustrated Man", that had authors like Egdar Allen Poe on Mars because their books were burned on earth; Dickens was there because of the ghosts in this story. The filmmakers seemed to believe that this allowed them to make this more of a horror movie than the predecessors; it managed to keep a straight PG rating, but I won't be surprised if the board considered bumping it up to PG-13.This re-telling of the classic tale of redemption is not completely removed of redeeming qualities. Technically, the special effects of this movie are great. My wife noticed two references of people wishing Scrooge good health even though the good will was one-sided at that time. I also liked this version having Cratchett tell the postscript.However, the story is as strong as Scrooge. Jim Carey's Scrooge comes across as creepy from scene one. And the special effects are the star here, having Scrooge shrunk to mouse size at one point and being chased by ghostly horses for a long sequence.My favorite version is Patrick Stewart's, where the actor holds his own with the special effects in that rendition. I also think Allistair Sims' was a much superior version. In fact, the Muppets was better (I haven't seen Mickey's, but I wouldn't be surprised if I like that one better as well).
summary: Only A Ghost Of The Greatness Of This Story

reviewText: I read A Christmas Carol when I was a kid. It was an abridged version, if I recall. So I am familiar with the story, not the book. I was watching the special features on this movie, and they were talking about how this book, even though it was written so long ago, really lends itself well to the animation process, because there are so many things actors can't physically do. And, this is the most faithful adaptation ever. Of course, if you watch the special features on any movie, even one that got horrible reviews, you will hear the actors and backstage people brag about how well they interpreted everything, what a fine cast they had, how perfectly it all came about, etc.Well, I did enjoy the movie. I enjoyed the animation. I can't really say how faithful it was to the book because I read it too long ago. But the basic story seemed to be there. Scrooge's change from penny-pinching to generous seemed a little abrupt to me. It seemed more from fear than learning. I can agree that they did things that were physically impossible and needed animation for. But then I wonder... why did they use motion capture? They had to set up all those weird contraptions to move around the actors, and then animate most of it anyway. Doesn't that just make it all a lot harder? Like doing it twice? They said (bragged) in the special features that using all the dots on the actors' faces allowed them to capture all the nuances of the actors' expressions. But then, animators on regular computer-animated movies are pretty proud of the expressions they come up with for their characters, too. I don't really get it. Their characters didn't look any more expressive then characters in movies like Shrek. I think they just made more work for themselves. But what the heck. The actors said it was a lot of fun.Well anyway, I enjoyed WATCHING the movie. I didn't get to see the 3-D version. I'm not a Christmas Carol aficionado with tons of things to compare it to. And I didn't have any little kids to scare. So it was a fun diversion.

reviewText: In the hands of Robert Zemeckis and Jim Carrey, Ebenezer Scrooge's tale delivers moments of true emotion - frightening, heartbreaking and uplifting. Yet, neither the 3-D animation nor Carrey's multi-character act elevate this version to the status of a Christmas classic.I preface I'm writing this review as a father of two sons (ages 8 and 6). We popped popcorn, poured glasses of Arnold Palmer and slipped into our pajamas for a family movie night. Having recently enjoyedThe Muppet Christmas Carol, I hoped my sons could enjoy (and follow) a gloomier interpretation of Dickens' classic that followed the original story closer than I had expected.Zemeckis employs the performance-capture technique previously used inThe Polar ExpressandBeowulf. The animation provides some amazing visuals, making it possible for Scrooge to fly Victorian England or shrink to mouse size for an icicle ride across rooftops. The ghost of Marley and the Ghost of Christmas Future were exceptionally scary (my six-year jumped when Marley's visage first appeared on Scrooge's doorknocker). However, the animation distracts as much as it dazzles, especially during longer stretches of dialogue. Aside from the skeletal Scrooge, Zemeckis envisions the rest of the cast as a fleshy, pig-faced people whose ugliness is off-putting.Scrooge is an amalgamation of Carrey's previous roles. You'll see a sneer that echoes Count Olaf fromLemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Eventsand then hear a laugh reminiscent of The Grinch fromHow the Grinch Stole Christmas. Carrey's performances as the Ghosts of Christmases Past, Present and Future are for vanity's sake. My six-year old detected the same actor played Scrooge and the Ghosts, a revelation that only served to pull him from the narrative.Robin Wright Penn, Gary Oldman, Cary Elwes and Bob Hoskins join Carrey in playing multiple roles. It is hard to understand why though because only Oldman, who portrays both Jacob Marley and Bob Cratchit, delivers two unique and satisfying performances. Marley is gruesome (much more horrifying than the Ghost of Christmas Future), while Cratchit is endearing and childlike, especially so during his commute home on Christmas Eve.In summary, this movie is a mess and falls well short of being a Christmas classic. Dickens classic proves beyond the creative talents of Carrey and Zemeckis, who are unsure how to present this tale. Dark and gloomy dialogue is followed byTom and Jerryaction scenes.Rating: Two stars.If you have young children, I recommendThe Muppet Christmas Carolinstead.
summary: Dickens classic proves beyond the creative talents of Carrey and Zemeckis
Title: Disney's A Christmas Carol

reviewText: I'm a fan of all Christmas Carol adaptations, even the Muppet one, and at the beginning of this movie I thought "wow, this could really be good" but it turned out to be disappointing.The problem I have with the movie, just my personal opinion, is it tries to alternate between serious scenes and slapstick humor and the mix just doesn't work (for me). Some scenes are recreated in a serious, dramatic way that really convey the spirit of the book.  The passing scenes of 19th century London life add a lot of atmosphere and Carrey does a great (serious) job with the voices.  Then - bam! - some visual gag is thrown in that's reminiscent of Carrey's physical comedy in other movies or a Bugs Bunny cartoon and you're thinking "where did that come from?"; then just as abruptly it switches back to the standard dramatic story.  The physical comedy might work for little kids but the movie also has some scenes that are too scary/disturbing for young children, so who exactly is their audience?  The last straw for me was a chase scene (really, a chase scene) that was clearly thrown in to show off the particle/water/physics effects of their animation engine, as if we haven't all seen enough animated water by now; you could almost hear the programmers saying "oh! oh! can we throw this in, it will look so cool."If it was supposed to be a comedy, it should have been lighthearted throughout.  If it was supposed to demonstrate that they could make a great Christmas Carol using animation (which they could have) they should have left out the shtick.

reviewText: Director Robert Zemeckis (The Polar Express, Forrest Gump) has scored again with this excellent animated version of Charles Dickens' classic holiday tale.  Jim Carrey stars as Ebenezer Scrooge, a crotchety old man who cares nothing about others or the holiday season.  He prefers to spend his time alone in his office or home, sitting in front of the fire.  He also belittles his employee Bob Cratchit (Gary Oldman), despite his young son's illness.On one such evening, Scrooge is in his customary place in front of the fireplace when a ghostly spirit visits him.  The spirit informs Scrooge that he is the Ghost of Christmas Past, and he takes Scrooge on a journey to the Christmases he had as a child and young man.  Scrooge sees where he went to school, and the holiday ball he attended with a girl that later became his wife.  The marriage ended in divorce.  Another spirit, The Ghost of Christmas Present, shows Scrooge the events of the current holiday, including the Cratchit family toasting him for his supplying Bob with a job.  Finally, the Ghost of Christmas Future shows Scrooge close to death, and the town members are rejoicing his passing.  Also, the Cratchits mourn the loss of Tiny Tim.All of these spirits have a profound effect on Scrooge himself.  Soon, he's singing carols in the street, skating behind carriages, and asking people for forgiveness for the way he treated them in the past.  No one is more surprised at Scrooge's miraculous transformation than Bob Cratchit.This is an excellent movie.  I've been a Zemeckis fan for years, and my family and I watch "The Polar Express" every Christmas season.  I'm sure "A Christmas Carol" will become regular holiday viewing for us, too.  The special effects in the film are astounding, and the story contains a fine moral lesson to be learned.  Make "A Christmas Carol" part of your regular holiday viewing.  Your family will love it.  Highly recommended.
summary: A Wonderful New Animated Film Version of Charles Dickens' Christmas Classic

reviewText: Motion Capture gets slightly better with every film that Zemeckis makes, but why in California's holy name does he keep making them? With Polar Express and this one, they are both stories which strain under his efforts to make them feature length through pointless lengthy action, over-dramatic pauses, and obvious hamming on the CG process.If you don't know what I'm talking about, then observe as you and your friends look at each other saying, "why doesn't he just get on with it?", and sigh loudly as moments are stretched intolerably. There's a "roller-coaster" sequence near the end that made me almost walk out on it. On the upside, the performance capture of Scrooge is pretty good, and each frame looks like a painting. So: hats off, Modelers, Lighting Directors, and Rigging Directors! Get out and support those guys, and look for the amazing, magical Geordie Martinez in the rigging and animation credits, and shout "HUZZAH!"

reviewText: Over the years I've seen at least a dozen versions of Dickens's "A Christmas Carol", and this one, dynamic and evocative, ranks among the very best, I saw it in an Imax theater in three D, and the special effects were stunning. The very rapidly moving aerial views of London were spectacular with a beautiful shot of St. Paul's Cathedral. Victorian England came to life because the director had paid attention to detail, authenticity. The wintry, slippery streets of London were part of the atmospherics.I was never really aware that Scrooge was being played by Jim Carrey because the make-up and computer effects similar to "Polar Express" submerged and camouflaged the person. He did a great job, even better by my lights because I've never been much of a Carrey fan. The sharp jutting chin in the young and old Scrooge reminded me of a character drawn by Toulouse-Lautrec. Scrooge was amazingly thin and emaciated. The three ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future are all played by Carrey though I never realized until I read the credits.The movie was fast-paced. I have seen rather stately, pokey versions in the past, but this one zipped along as it concentrated almost entirely on Scrooge. The three visits of the three Christmas ghosts initiated by the dead partner Marley were done with alacrity. Scrooge goes flying off into space like a rocket.This film has a comic book or graphic novel look to it with some scenes looking like drawings, paintings that have come to life. There are some funny touches as when Scrooge balks or shows a wise guy side as he talks to the ghosts. You get the essentials of the story, a lot of action and movement, without being bogged down by some of the old familiar stuff. The Roger de Coverley dance in Scrooge's past was well done. Some of the characters in the dance sequence are Pickwickian. Scrooge's stinginess and acquisitiveness are evoked by the stacks of coins on his desk as a young and old man.The street scenes were cleverly recreated. Kids were rolling hoops with sticks, sliding down icy hills on their feet which Bob Cratchit (Gary Oldman) imitates later. Some kids hitched themselves onto the rear of fast-moving wagons and foot-skied behind, and Scrooge does it after his redemption. Of course the theme of the story is how the real spirit of Christmas can bring about redemption.It has a truly Dickensian flavor using some of his actual dialogue, description and narration. The Cratchits' prosaic roasted goose inspires Scrooge to send them a turkey.For kiddies and adults in the audience the story comes alive with added dimensions. This is a reimagined version, done with originality and creativity. It may be too scary for little tots.
summary: The Triumph of a Reimagined Christmas Carol
Title: Disney's A Christmas Carol

reviewText: Story:This is VERY different in many respects from the Dickens story. There are some glaring changes that really take away from the beauty of this classic story.Changes for 3D effect:1. The "flying" effect with the Ghost of Christmas Present was not, was not even implied, in the Dickens story.2. Scrooge being chased around the streets of London after meeting the Ghost of Christmas Future.3. Scrooge being shrunk to the size of a mouse, running around the London sewers, snowboarding with an icicle, and getting nearly pounded by Joe the rag and bones man.Changes made for no apparent reason:1. Many important scenes are left out that show the progression of Scrooge from greedy miser to keep of Christmas all year long.2. The Ghost of Christmas Present dies, rots to a skeleton, turns to dust, and is blown away by the wind.One change that really, really got on my nerves was the Ghost of Christmas Present making a dig at "men of the cloth." I don't know if the writer/director/producer was trying to be overtly anti-Christian here, but that's surely the way it comes off. (Which makes you wonder why they'd make a movie about the miracle of Christmas if they want to be anti-Christian.)The result is a movie that falls well short of the great film it could have been. For one, it scared my daughter (3 years old) quite a bit; the movie is loud and spends a lot of time getting "in your face" for the 3D effects. Also, have I mentioned that the Ghost of Christmas Present, who of course looks a lot like Santa, DIES...and TURNS INTO A SKELETON!There are some nice extras on the disk. I like watching the technical features about motion-capture, but I had to laugh out loud when the directors, actors, producer, etc. were talking about "how true they stayed to Dickens' story."The story adaptation gets 0 stars, all the little changes add up to this being not a very good telling of the story. The motion-capture, including how amazingly lifelike the facial features came out, gets 5 stars.
summary: Horrible adaptation of the book. Good FX though

reviewText: A sad, convoluted effort that leaves one cold. First, the animators seemed to not be able to decide if the characters were "realistic" or "cartoons."  The result is that too many characters simply look deformed.  Second, just because they could do animated "fly-bys" impossible with live film, they beat the concept to death with too many shots that defy physics. But, worst of all, the film seems to have been infected with that subtle sense of meanness that is lurking around the edges of so many Jim Carey movies. And this is one instance where it simply doesn't work. The Christmas morning ending lightens up considerably..too bad the bulk of the film was not like it. And, although taken from the book, there is a gratuitous swipe at clergy or "men of the cloth" that has nothing to do with the plot, but is social commentary from the 1800's. Essentially stating (by the Ghost of Christmas Present) that men of the cloth have little to do with the spirit of Christmas reeks of some kind of agenda that is totally out of place in this film. Buy the Alastair Simm version for a real treat or even the delightful British 70's musical version, "Scrooge", if you want to feel good.  And God bless us, every one!
summary: To Much Tech, Too Mean, Not Enough Heart.

reviewText: Other reviewers have commented on the acting performances of Jim Carrey et al in Disney's new animated ("live action" performance capture) version of A CHRISTMAS CAROL by Charles Dickens. I'll simply say that Carrey is brilliant in his multiple roles; he's the Scrooge for the Ages.What I really want to rave about is the visual special FX of this production, especially the 3-D format, which will most assuredly be nominated for an Oscar. The opening sequence, in which the virtual camera soars over and through a marvelously re-created 1842 London, is worth the price of admission alone. My wife and I watched the film from the front row of an invitation-only studio screening. During a couple of scenes depicting falling snow, it seemed, through our 3-D glasses, that we could reach out and touch the descending flakes. And one is tempted to flinch backwards as the blackened, skeletal, claw-hand of the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come apparently reaches out from the screen.It's been decades since I read the Dickens classic. (At least, I think I read it; memory fails.) I suspect that literary purists may object to embellishments of the original story, and over-protective parents may judge it too dark for small children. I say to those, "Get over it!" The visuals will simply knock your socks off and I'd award six stars if the rating system allowed such.You'll thank yourself if you make the decision to go see A CHRISTAMAS CAROL (2009) on the Big Screen. I'll happily go see it a second time, which isn't something I can usually say about an animated feature.

reviewText: One of the most impressively effective and beautiful 3D movies ever rendered for the new 3D generation.I have to say that I saw this movie in 3D at theaters.. and it was ok. I say that because I thoroughly enjoyed it, but didn't think the 3D was as phenomenal as other films. I was hesitant to purchase it again on Bluray-3D simply for this fact, but got it through Amazon's Disney discount offer, which made the purchase at a value. Wow, was I wrong with the 3D effects.The movie looks GORGEOUS on my 3D television. The story is amazingly well done, if not a bit creepy in some parts. It does push the boundaries of a PG film. Some parts, especially the Jacob Marley and third ghost of Christmas Future, are almost too frightening for small children, especially in 3D. But older kids (~8-10 yrs old) would probably love it, even if they do not understand what is being said. The movie uses almost exact prose from the Dickens masterpiece, therefore adults would understand the speech more than their children- after all, the original story by Mr. Charles was written as a ghost story intended for adults rather than for children. The underlying themes and ideas are great for all ages, but better understood and directed towards the lives of adults in this corruptive world that we live in.Pay no mind to the harsh reviews of others here on Amazon, the movie is excellent. A classic! Jim Carrey truly delivers his best performance, something that my father will watch and be impressed to know that it is actually the goofy, suggestive man that he once despised as Ace Ventura. A redeeming performance on his behalf for a movie of redemption during the holiday season. Zemeckis adds his eye-candy flavor to an already well-established tale to make this a fun and rewarding experience that rivals other holiday films for the best movie to enjoy next to a crackling fire on Christmas Eve. Oscar-worthy performances by all, especially Carrey. Rewarding 3D effects that truly immerse you into the adventure. Well worth its place in everyone's holiday collection. Easily five stars.

reviewText: I just saw this one in the theater.  I chose the 3-D showing.  You know the famous Charles Dickens' story.  It is the same basic story line, but done in the computer animation that makes the characters look about as close to human as possible, at least for now.  I almost forget they are not real, except the eyes never look quite right.  The computer graphics are phenomenal, the color is beautiful, and the picture is sharp.  If you saw Disney's Polar Express, it is the same animation quality.  It is hard for me to believe this is Jim Carrey.  It doesn't even sound like him.  He does a fantastic job with Scrooge.  I watch the Scrooge story every Christmas season, probably several times.The story begins on Christmas Eve.  Jacob Marley has died and Scrooge has made arrangements with the undertaker for a nice wooden box.  Scrooge reluctantly pays the undertaker and whisks around to scarf up the tuppences that lay on Marley's eyes, telling a young boy that it is money (and not to be wasted).The sun is shining brightly outside and the snow is lightly falling, providing a multi-dimensional effect while wearing your 3-D glasses.  Snow falls through most of the picture.  We hear singing and move through the streets of old London, watching the street vendors hulk their wares.  Scrooge moves through the streets, grouching the whole time.  It's what he does best, you know.  As Scrooge enters the storefront marked by the sign "Scrooge and Marley,"  the "M" begins to wiggle.Fast forward 7 years, to the anniversary of Marley's death.  We find Scrooge and Bob Cratchett working in the cold, cold office on Christmas Eve.  Cratchett is freezing his little buns off but dare not place another chunk of coal on the fire.  As a matter of fact, I think the coal box had a lock on it.  (Heck, one piece of coal is enough.  Who needs feeling in their fingers anyway?)  Nephew Fred stops by to visit Uncle Scrooge and gets the bah humbug routine.  The two gents come in, asking for a donation for charity and Scrooge delivers the famous "Let them die and decrease the surface population" line.Scrooge closes for the evening, reminding Cratchett it is not fair that he be off all day on Christmas, being paid for no work, and he need be there early on December 26!  They part company, Cratchett scurrying to be merry and Scrooge grouching home to be Scrooge.The fun begins as we see Scrooge's door knocker come alive, glowing with Marley's face!  Scrooge is seriously creeped out, even after he runs upstairs and locks everthing behind him.  As he cowers in his chair, the 4 bells above the inside of his door begin to ring, no BANG--loudly, followed by the entrance of (guess who?) J-A-C-O-B  M-A-R-L-E-Y!Of course, like I said, you know the story.  The 3 ghosts visit and the computer animations allow for a nice level of visual entertainment as they take Scrooge to the past, present, and the possible future.  Through a mixture of heart-touching rememberances, fear, and compassion, they remind Scrooge that it is NOT all about HIM!  This story is an excellent reminder of the importance of carrying love and compassion and opening your heart to others, for without our heart-centers, we dry up inside.This is a great rendition of the classic, I don't care how many times you have seen the story before.Disney done it again! Enjoy!
summary: A Great Animation Rendition of the Scrooge Story!

reviewText: First, just because the Disney name is attached, do not think for a moment that this is a movie suitable for young children.  It is not.  Who it is suitable for is fully grown adults.  The visual effects are absolutely stunning, and the story is very faithful to the actual Dickens book.  Frankly, it can be quite disturbing to young viewers.  But it can also be disturbing to adult viewers in a way that Dickens himself would most likely have approved.  In fact, I think it relays the message he intended to relay: Fear death now while ye yet live and can make changes.I knew from the moment that Jacob Marley made his deathly appearance, wrapped in chains that he forged in life, that this was going to be a moving experience.Scrooge: "What do you want with me?"Marley (dragging his chains): "Ooooh, much! ... Aaaaaahg!"Throughout his conversation with Scrooge, he is preoccupied with looking at the chains he is bound with.  "I wear the chains I forged in life.  I made it link by link and yard by yard.  Can you recognize it's pattern?  Can you imagine the lengths and weight of the chain you bear?  Yours is a ponderous chain".The ghost of Christmas past is ghostly, and his voice is like the flickering of the candle he is represented as.  The Ghost of Christmas Present dies as though by heart attack while a giant bell tolls.  And the Ghost of Christmas yet to Come is, frankly, frightening - even to an adult.  He appears as nothing more than something like a three dimensional shadow.  The kind of thing that makes me wish I had seen this one, at least, in 3D on the big screen.The story is fantastically faithful to the original text as penned by Dickens.  The dialogue is fantastic, even by today's standards: "Would you so soon put out, with your worldly hands, the light that I give?"Just.... WOW.

reviewText: "A Christmas Carol" is excellent! This is how the story goes: Ebenezer Scrooge begins the Christmas holiday with his usual miserly contempt, barking at his faithful clerk and his cheery nephew. But when the ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Yet to Come take him on an eye-opening journey revealing truths Old Scrooge is reluctant to face, he must open his heart to undo years of ill will before it's too late.The cast led by Jim Carrey (as Scrooge / Ghost of Christmas Past / Scrooge as a Young Boy / Scrooge as a Teenage Boy / Scrooge as a Young Man / Scrooge as a Middle-Aged Man / Ghost of Christmas Present / Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come) is excellent! The screenplay (based on Charles Dickens' novel) & directing by Robert Zemeckis (also produced) (who also directed "The Polar Express" (2004, also produced and wrote the screenplay), the "Back To The Future" (1985, also wrote the story and screenplay, 1989, also wrote the story & 1990, also wrote the story), "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" (1988), "Forrest Gump" (1994), "Contact" (1997, also produced), "Cast Away" (2000, also produced), "What Lies Beneath" (2000, also produced), & "Beowulf" (2007, also produced) is excellent!The music by Alan Silvestri (who also did the music to Zemeckis' films since "Romancing The Stone" (1984), he also did the music to "G.I. Joe: The Rise Of Cobra" (2009) & "Night At The Museum: Battle Of The Smithsonian" (2009) is excellent! The cinematography by Robert Presley (who also did the cinematography to "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent! The film editing by Jeremiah O'Driscoll (who also did the film editing to "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent! The casting by Scot Boland, Victoria Burrows (both of did the casting to "The Polar Express" & the upcoming "The Lovely Bones" (2009) & Nina Gold (who also did the casting to "Bewoulf") is excellent! The production design by Doug Chiang (who also did the production design to "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent! The art direction by Marc Gabbana (who was a concept artist on "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") & Mike Stassi (who was an assistant art director on the upcoming "Avatar", "The Polar Express" & "Bewoulf"), he also did the art direction to the upcoming "Alice In Wonderland" (2010) is excellent! The set decoration by Karen O'Hara (who also did the set decoration to the upcoming "Alice In Wonderland", "What Lies Beneath", "Cast Away", "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent!This is an excellent telling of Charles Dickens' novel and one of the best telling of Scrooge's story ever made as a movie. This is another motion-capture hit for Zemeckis. Jim Carrey is impressive in 8 roles that were given to him by Zemeckis.

reviewText: I was worried when I learned Jim Carrey would star in Disney's production of "A Christmas Carol". There has never been a more perfect holiday tale and I was concerned about the possibility of an over-the-top Carrey performance. As it turns out, Jim Carrey was wonderful...HOWEVER, since seeing the movie I'm wondering what the developers of the project were thinking? The first fifteen minutes of the film had me believing I was viewing a version  that would join the Alastair Sim and George C. Scott versions in the holiday classics hall-of-fame. However, as the film continued the purity of Dickens' story was compromised with chase scenes and a shrinking Ebenezer Scrooge. Come on!! The screen time could have been better used telling the complete story and developing the other major characters...Bob Cratchit, Tiny Tim, his nephew Fred and Belle. These characters were crucial to Scrooge's reclamation and their importance were, for the most part, trivialized. There were stellar moments...for example, the visitation by Marley's ghost and the scene in the Cratchit home after Tiny Tim's death, but they were too few and far between. Visually the film was absolutely stunning! Some of the "special effects" were wonderful...others just didn't fit the story. The problem with the film, I believe, is that the target audience was not well defined. It appeared at times to target an adult audience and then it would abruptly shift to some rediculous scene clearly intended to satisfy children. If I had wanted to see a children's version I would have rented "Mickey's Christmas Carol" or "A Muppet Christmas Carol". The film is basically true to Dickens' marvelous story but is, at best, a ghostly apparition (pun intended) of the original...it just didn't have enough substance. Entertaining? Yes. Worthwhile seeing? Yes, particularing at an IMAX theater. But if you love Charles Dickens' masterpiece, be prepared to set your expectations a little lower.
Title: Disney's A Christmas Carol

reviewText: This caricature of Charles Dickens' wonderful Christmas story was not only a complete disappointment, it was a pointless attempt at humor.  Beginning with completely skipping over Ebenezer Scrooge's walk home from his office on Christmas Eve when the first hint of something unusual happening (the ghost horses and hearse)became evident, to the Ghost of Christmas Past portrayed as a disembodied head with its skull on fire, hovering over the ghostly shoulders of a weird little body, and on to an almost total bastardization of a Christmas classic, the kindest thing I can think of to say about this film is, "Shame on Disney."I was aware before I bought this DVD, of course, that the characters were not real people, but rather computer graphics, but that seemed like it might be kind of a fun film.  I have the movie "The Polar Express," and there are no "real people" in that either, and most of the Polar Express voices belong to Tom Hanks, and that's a most enjoyable film.  But as it turns out here, Jim Carrey as the voice of Scrooge, minus that fantastic talent for visual comedy, was a real loss of what I thought was good potential for an enjoyable version of A Christmas Carol.I agree with the statement of a couple other reviewers that there are a few questionable scenes in what would most likely be considered a children's movie since it was made by Disney, scenes that might be frightening to young children.  Having viewed this movie, if I had young children, I'd be very reluctant to allow them to watch this one.For a delightful presentation of a different spin on the Christmas Carol movie, the musical version "Scrooge" is the best so far.
